column1: 12	This debate has clarified for me that the government shouldn't really be in the marriage business.  Let the churches perform marriages for whomever they think fit
column2: and let the government simply record the marriages or civil unions and grant equal rights to them all.  As for plural "marriages
column3:
they exist, but there is not a sizable part of the population which supports them.  That is a different debate for another day, and the issues are quite different.  In my mind, the purpose of marriage or civil union is to provide support to individuals, especially when they are raising children.  Some of the most monogamous couples I know are gay, and they are some of the best parents too.  Notably, the main argument in favor of same-sex marriage is based on the premise that same-sex couples can and should have the same rights and protections as heterosexual couples, and this implies recognition of their relationships through legal marriage. Therefore, legalizing same-sex marriage is the best solution.

14	Battlefield is boring because you always know where the enemy is and you don't have to go get them. You can just drive around being bored and the maps are too big to go out of your way to kill someone. On the other hand, in Call of Duty, you're thrown into the meat grinder of survival with only three magazines of ammo and skills that take time to develop. Weapons in Call of Duty are realistic, except for the ATV-4 which is not a guided munition. In the end, it boils down to personal preference: some people prefer the more tactical, slower pace of Battlefield, while others enjoy the chaotic, adrenaline rush of Call of Duty.
15	I always hear people discussing the death penalty and how it should be implemented more often. I personally am undecided on this issue, but in my opinion, the death penalty is used as a form of retaliation for the worst of crimes (much like how putting someone’s head on a pike was used in the past). If this is true, shouldn't we as a society want as many people as possible to witness the consequences of these heinous acts? Televising executions in the United States may just serve to educate the public on what the death penalty actually entails (and thus, may very well change people’s beliefs on the matter).
16	You cannot impose democracy on a country through military force, as it requires the consent of the people for such a government to be established.  Muslim countries lack the Enlightenment background that was present during the formation of the United States, and thus are not able to form a secular constitutional republic based on the rule of law derived from the Quran.  Therefore, any attempts to enforce western democracy on these countries will be unsuccessful, and will likely be met with opposition.  In the West, we have the wall of separation between church and state, allowing individuals to follow the dictates of their own conscience.  Muslim countries must undergo their own Enlightenment before democracy can have a chance of succeeding, and any form of western democracy imposed upon them will only lead to further chaos and instability.  To counter this, the West should focus on keeping weak control through military force, while avoiding the occurrence of blowback, as seen in the Middle East.
17	Law is an obligation of the society to which a person has to abide. Any law that violates your rights is morally wrong and should not be upheld. Breaking a law is dangerous when you are prone to get caught, however, people tend to bend laws and break laws in cases where the penalty is not severe, such as speeding, not wearing seat belts, and the like. Any law is right if it does not invade the realms of human rights and religious beliefs of a person. If you are unhappy with any law, you can fight it in the court of justice or ask your legislature to change/modify it. However, this is a very tiring and exhaustive process.

22	The Stormcloaks are presented as a villainous force due to their racism, abuse and mistreatment of those who are different from them, as well as their use of the thu'um to assassinate the High King. This makes them the clear antagonists of the civil war in Skyrim, with the Empire as the obvious good guys. While they may not have any redeeming qualities, the Empire does have the more noble motivation of simply wanting to protect their land from invasion while the Stormcloaks are solely concerned with breaking away and forming their own state. This adds a layer of complexity to the conflict, making the civil war questline and story weaker.

column4: we have the right to know what the government is doing-- since it's with our money.  Governments take our money
column5: then use the fruits of their theft against us. Anyone arguing that the 4th Amendment protects our privacy from the government is living in the past.  The 4th has been effectively nullified by SSNs
column6: gun records
column7: increasing search & seizure to look for a "probable cause"
column9: and the fact that the government is so vast and powerful that businesses are being forced to collude with bureaucrats and hand over what little privacy we had left.

column1: 49	It has been proven to the satisfaction of many people
column2: but there are some that are extremely hard to convince
column3: for a variety of reasons. These reasons are mainly faith based
column4: in that they have faith in the government
column5: and do not want to believe that their government could murder three thousand of its own citizens. They will all wake up in due time
column6: probably when the country is under Martial law
column7: with curfews imposed
column8: and they become prisoners in their own house. That's for the lucky ones of course. The less lucky will become prisoners in the 600 or so concentration camps which have been built around the country
column9: and are already manned and waiting for their presence.
